EDITORIAL.
2,2, 2t

F, at the commencement of the season, there was any doubt as to the
success of the Undergraduate Football Team, it has certainly been
It It
It
It
effectually dispelled. The splendid showing which our men made
1St
at the Saint John's game, the defeat of the University of Maryland,
the large crowds at Homewood on the 23rd and 28th, and the genF•
eral spirit and enthusiasm which have characterized these last few
weeks of the seas)n, are all certainly gratifying and convincing of
the pronounced success of the new regime. Never before have we
turned out a team so full of grit and hard-working spirit as the one
that lined up against Saint John's. Never before did enthusiasm
and "Hopkins spirit" reach so high a pitch as then. Never did the people of Baltimore
show such interest as to stand for two hours on a muddy field, in a driving rain, in order to
see Hopkins play football. A few may have done so before now—but when the number
exceeds a thousand, as in this case, it becomes remarkable.
The fact that the people were interested is owing to the real and hearty interest shown
and felt by the student-body. And the students were interested not only because it was a
Hopkins team, but an Undergraduate team, made up of their personal friends—not "individual stars from all over the country" (as someone has called our friends, the "medics ").
And because they were personal friends the students were with them heart and soul.
The Maryland game was less pleasing. Oil and water will not mix, and the ill feeling
displayed by the men from Lombard Street was in sharp contrast with the eager, yet friendly,
rivalry of our brass-buttoned friends from Annapolis. The students of the University of
Maryland don't lose much love over us, but what difference does that make, after all? We won
the game, and won it fairly and squarely.
Our narrow defeat by Western Maryland, our scoreless tie with Saint John's, and our
victory over the University of Maryland, all lead us to think and to hope that the Undergraduate team is something that will be with us always.

OME people say: "What will become of the Medical Students who
still love the game and desire exercise ?" It has been suggested
by a prominent member of the Faculty that the "medics," having
their own campus and their own leisure hours, should get together
and organize a team of their own • and practice at the Medical
School. They could then play the Undergrates at Homewood on
Wednesday afternoons. This would give them plenty of exercise,
and would improve the Undergraduate team without interferring
with its regular practices.

NE more word of comment on the football season. When the last
issue of the NEWS—LETTER appeared the enthusiasm over the Saint
John's game—to be played the next day—was at its height. The
short editorial on the poor rooting of the season was therefore
unnecessary. The showing made by the rooters at the last two
games was as good as that of our team—or nearly—and the hearty
support they received must be gratifying to each and every member
of our team.

Well, the first Hopkins Cotillon is over. It was a great success, of course. In fact
things are generally a success here. Everything went off in fine style last Saturday night and
reflected credit on the Board of Governors of the Cotillon Club. There will be another dance
next month—on the thirty-first of January, we believe. We hope that all who were at
McCoy Hall last Saturday will be back again then, and the unfortunate ones who were obliged
to be away will be able to come next time. We say "obliged" because surely no one would
be silly enough to stay away if he could help it.

With the football season past, and track yet to come, it does seem as if more interest
should be shown in the Glee Club. We do not speak of the Mandolin Club because it is getting
along excellently. But the Glee Club is not. With so good a leader as Mr. Ruth, there is no
excuse for so poor an attendance and such lack of enthusiasm and interest. Things have
been "whooping up" around here lately. Let's "whoop up" the Glee Club.

The grim approach of exams. next week prevented the publication of two issues of the

NEws-LETTER before Christmas. An issue should have appeared last Friday and one today
week, but even Editors are human and exams, have to be studied for! The NEWS—LETTER
wishes you all success in the exams., a very Merry Christmas and a fine time during the
holidays.

Where's your Hopkins Night, '08?

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE EARLY ENGLISH NOVELISTS.

SmoLLETT.
In Smollett we find a man who showed life
as it was, probably better than did either
Richardson or Fielding. He, being the inferior
writer, did not improve his characters with
the jovial good fellowship of Fielding, nor
with the fanatical rigor of Richardson. And
thus, be it said to the shame of humanity, his
characters, being inferior in qualities, exceed
in truth, but only in one side of the truth.
Smollett was a more literal copyist of the side
of life•he chose, but he chose only one side.
To the good, the high, and the pure in life,
he was blind. His characters are, without
exception, repulsive creatures, almost incapable of a worthy emotion. In his preface he
gives his idea of the novel. For him it is a
convenient vehicle for satire; "the most entertaining and universally improving." His
characters appear to us as ruffians, yet Smollett regarded himself as a moralist, he considered himself a writer calculated to improve,
yet he repulses us.
Smollet always put his enemies in his books.
He was rancorous and implacable towards
them. In Roderick Random he draws us a
picture of his grandfather, his cousins, an
apothecary for whom he worked; all of whom
he detested and with good reason.
His first literary undertaking was a tragedy,
The Regicide, in which he had always an
overweening pride. He considered it,(a drama
in blank verse, upon the murder of James I.,)
a piece of great merit. But its results were
most unhappy to him. For ten years he clung
to it, polished it, changed it, and finally in
1749, after the appearance of Roderick Random, he published it. Needless to say, it was
a flat failure, "unappreciated," he said. He
had passed his medical examinations when he
first came to London. His money gave out
shortly afterwards and he obtained a berth as
surgeon's mate on the Cumberland. Here he
obtained his material for Roderick Random.
He soon left the navy and came back to London, where he practiced medicine with but
little success.
He had failed as a dramatist, as a doctor
and as a satirist, and he turned his attention

to the novel. Here he succeeded. The novel
was then popular, and in 1748 he catered to
the popular taste and produced Roderick
Random.
Roderick Random is not a character that
would appeal to our twentieth century minds.
Smollett, always an imitator of LeSage, here
follows out the "plan" of Gil Bias, a plan as
old as Petronius Arbiter. It is merely a
hurly-burly, rough and tumble story of life on
the road; but yet it contains a great deal of
Smollett's own life. The grandfather and
the cousins of Random are no other than
those of Smollett, with all their bad qualities
thrust into the foreground. The story of the
life at sea is taken from Smollett's own life.
He had been through all that he described
there. Yes, Roderick Random, poor derelict
of fate, is no other than Smollett himself. He
drags in his own unsuccessful Regicde under
the disguise of Mr. Melopoyn's drama. He
tells of his own experiences with the managers.
He attacks his former patron under the name
of Lord Strutwell, a man of large promises.
Here, too, he shows the influence of social
conditions upon him. Roderick Random is a
gentleman born; Strap is only a common
lackey: therefore Strap owes everything to
Random. He must be his devoted slave. In
France he finds Random forsaken and penniless. He comes to his aid, gives him his
money and his clothes; in fact, becomes his
valet. Of course, Random accepts. It is only
his due. And then, after taking Strap's money,
he may come home in a bad humor and vent
his spite upon the poor boy. Random finally
finishes by marrying Strap off to his wife's
maid, whom he knows to be a low woman.
But here Smollett rises to his highest as a
moralist,—the story of poor Miss Williams, a
true story, and one terrible in its very truth.
It is not fiction. When Smollett penned those
few pages, he was depicting one of the most
horrible phases of humanity. It is not only
Miss Williams' story, but it is the story of
many such another. There is no squeamishness or prudery here; it is a plain fact told in
a plain way. We all see the depravity of
human nature in its most appalling form. It
is a sickening presentation of a fearful truth.
In 1750, Peregrine Pickle was published.
Smollett introduces here people known to him

THE NEWS-LETTER.

and draws them so well that they are easily
recognized. Vet Peregrine Pickle is the best
thing he ever wrote. Of course the hero, like
all of Smollett's other heroes, is a hopeless
reprobate. Like Roderick Random, the novel
is made up of a string of adventures just
linked together, and, as a matter of fact, there
is no reason that it should ever come to an
end, except that, in the course of time, the
hero, being mortal, must die. But judging from
the modern Sherlock Holmes and Raffles, heroes
are perfectly able to come back to life and to
be run through countless volumes. Smollett,
as a humorist, strikes twelve in Peregrine
Pickle. Old Commodore Trunnion is one of
the most laughable characters I know, but he
is entirely different from any other of Smollett's characters. I always thought that he
got his idea for the commodore from Fielding's
Squire Western. However, in Peregrine Pickle
Smollett stamps himself as one of the foremost
humorists in the language. There is nothing
sharp and quick in his wit; it is of a very
broad order. If you can laugh at a comical
situation, and be impervious to the vulgarity
of it, you can enjoy Peregrine Pickle.
The weakest point in this novel is the longwinded account of the Lady of Quality. The
lady was the beautiful Lady Vane, whose
amours were described in her memoirs, which
Smollett practically reproduced. It is unnecessary, and it was put in chiefly for the benefit
of the scandal mongers.
His other novels are of much less importance
than these two. Ferdenand Count Fathom,
The Adventures of an Atom, Sir Launeelot
Graves, and Humphrey Clinker, complete the
list. Of these, the first and the last are
worthy of mention.
Ferdenand Count Fathom, is the adventures
of a young man, absolutely devoid of conscience, gratitude and courage, and incapable
of a genuine emotion. This admirable character betrays his master who had raised him,
lays traps for young girls, and does a variety of
other things on the same order. A more
sickening character has never been drawn in
the whole of English literature. Finally,
the hero reforms and marries a girl whom he
had ruined before. Virtue came out supreme.
But to say the least, it is not a moral or edifying tale.

5

Humphrey Clinker, is the last book Smollett
ever wrote, and in some respects the best of
them all. Thackery said it was the most
laughable book ever written. Certainly it is
the kindest Sm011ett ever wrote. In it he
forgives everybody, even his own relations.
What could be more laughable than old
Tabitha Brambles' persistent attempts at love.
The book is a veritable history. Smollett
wrote of his own country, Scotland. All in
all, HumPhrey Clinker is the most "good
natured" novel of Smollett's.
Smollett wrote of the low classes, and in
this respect he was the forerunner of Dickens.
But in turn, LeSage was the forerunner of
Smollett. It is only, however, in the class of
characters, that there is any resemblance to
Dickens. Smollett wrote of the low classes
because he knew them. His favorite trick
was to take for a hero a gentleman born, and
then run him, surrounded by the lowest
society in England, through numberless chapters.
The point in Smollett's novels most easily
assailed is the moral side. He claimed to be
a moralist, but is he? The story of poor Miss
Williams is undoubtedly written with the
moral object in view. It is held up in all its
horror. Vice is vice, and its consequences
are all put down. But with the exception of
this, I do not think that there is anything in
Smollett calculated to have a good moral
effect. Of course we can consider Fathom as
a sort of terrible example, but how many of
the readers do? Is there anything calculated
to have a moral effect in Peregrine Pickle? We
fairly split our sides over some parts of it, but
it doesn't make us any better. Smollett, I
think, uses the cloak of a moralist as a means
to introduce the low and the obscene. He has
neither the rigor of Richardson nor the open
bluffness of Fielding. He wants to be like
Fielding, but he hasn't the courage to he so
openly. No; Smollett is not moral. He is a
great humorist, but he is not a moralist.
With Smollett passed away the old rough
and tumble novel of humor, of life on the
road. It was for the best. They had diverted
the stream of literature towards the realms of
fiction. Their successors were mightier than
they were, but still we do not want to discard
them completely. At the present day they

THE NEWS-LETTER.

6

are but little read, and perhaps that is for the
best. There are two ways to be a moralist.
One is to drag the reader down through the
filth and mire of human depravity till, disgusted and nauseated, one turns in sheer desperation away. This is the course of the early
novelists. The other is to so inspire the
reader, with the beauty of the true and the
high things in life that the love for them
completely crowds out the low and the vulgar.
Here, one turns to the higher things, not
through disgust and hatred for the low, but
for the love of the better.
Let us appreciate Fielding, Richardson and
Smollett as best we can. They compose a
field of literature comparatively unread. I do
not seek to defend them, but I maintain that
they, with all their coarseness and obscenity,
are far better than our modern fiction. Perhaps it is better to let them stay unread. They
would not be appreciated by twentieth
century minds. Some would throw them
aside, half read, disgusted and sick of them.
Others would keep on in delight. To them it
would be a fresh supply of 'gay reading." A
few, a very few, would appreciate them. It
is to these few, then, that falls the duty to
keep alive and fresh the memory of RichardW.
son, Fielding and Smollett.
[THE END.]

"SONGES SONT MENSONGES."
"Thank you so much, Mr. Hall! Oh, this
is fine! I see, you're an expert; where did
you learn—no, please put the soft pillow
under my head and the other one—yes, that's
right; I hate to get the draught on my back
—oh, it's fine to be wrapped up so nicely.
Now I'll try to slumber a little while—I'm
sure I'll dream about you, Mr. Hall!"
"In that case, I needn't wish you pleasant
dreams, Miss Grosset."
"Well, of all the conceit!! Why are men so
conceited! Girls never are!"
"Never!"
"Now this irony again, this sardonic sneer!
It makes me nervous!"
"Sleep is good for overstrained nerves!"
"Thank you, I'll take the hint; I'll go to
sleep immediately. I won't say another word

to you, tonight, and I certainly shall not
dream about you!"
"Pleasant dreams then," came the dry
answer.
"You're a hopeless case, absolutely—"
This was the last he could hear of this
violent outburst of utter disgust, for the last
words were spoken from under the rug, which
she had drawn up over her face, to protect it
against the cool evening breeze.
For a few moments he stood there motionless, looking down on this huge pile of
cushions and rugs on the steamer-chair,
crowned by an aureola of beautiful auburn
hair beneath a white tam o'sbanter, and shaking his head he slowly walked away.
The big liner ploughed its way majestically
thru the exceptionally smooth waters of the
Atlantic Ocean. The quietude of the desert
reigned on board. All the passengers were
comfortably wrapped up in their steamerchairs, either enjoying a short after-dinner
nap, or dreaming with eyes wide open.
From the stern the soft, plaintive tunes of a
violin were heard, played by one of the crew
perchance in honor of his distant sweetheart.
Jack Hall was leaning over the railing, gazing down upon the silvery pathway caused by
the moon on the gentle undulating waves.
He could not help thinking of those dangerous green siren eyes, now closed in sleep
under the protecting rug. They had not
failed to bewitch him the first time he had
looked into then when at the first dinner on
board he had found her sitting next to him.
Since that moment he had been completely
under their spell and had become Eunice
Grosset's most faithful and perhaps most
successful suitor, cutting out all of his many
rivals.
He enjoyed the privilege of having his
steamer-chair next to hers, he was allowed to
wrap her up and arrange her numerous
pillows and to carry out her many small
orders. Sure, she was so sweet and fascinating and he felt as if they were friends of old
and he knew she felt the same way.
Jack Hall had not stirred for the last thirty
minutes, gazing upon the play of the moon
rays on the water it seemed to him as if some
mermaids were dancing there, and strange to
say, one of them was fixing her green phos-

THE NEWS-LETTER.

phorescent eyes upon him—why, she looked
like Eunice, he thought. "You're moonstruck, old chap," he murmured, •'I'll have
to tell Eunice about my vision." He found
Eunice sound asleep and so—faute de mieux
—followed her example and was soon slumbering away to the isle of dreams.
All of a sudden, the liner stopped abruptly,
throwing everyone on the floor. Shrieking,
running,—yelling. "Something wrong with
the propellers," howled the Chief Engineer
after a 'few moments of anxious expectation.
Two men were ordered to investigate. After
a short while they reappeared above the railing
—a broad grill on their faces. They reported
that the propellers were entangled in a mass
of sea-weed and that there were some mermaids down there, one of whom demanded
the youngest man on board to come down
to her immediately, or else the whole ship
would be wrecked.
Jack was looking around in order to find to
find tile poor chap who would have to sacrifice himself for the benefit of his fellowpassengers, when the Captain tipped him on
his shoulder. "Mr. Hall," he said, "the
Chief Steward after looking over the passenger
list, informs me, that you are the youngest
man, and so, I'm afraid, you're the man
wanted down there."
"What I, am I the youngest?" yelled Jack.
'Yes, I'm sorry.'
"So am I. I'm not going down there."
"Well we'll see about that" said the Captain cruelly, and before Jack knew what happened he felt himself lifted up by brutal hands
and thrown overboard. It seemed to him as
if he were flying thru the air for more than
an hour, before he finally safely landed in an
immense shell at the side of the beautiful mermaid who had stared at him, while he was
watching her dancing.
"Take this stone, sweet mortal, it will protect you from the waters," she said to our
speechless Jack, *handing him a- big emerald.
She then blew a silver-whistle and instantly
the shell began to sink slowly until it finally
landed before a large grot. The mermaid
took Jack by the hand and led him thru the
labyrinth of passage until she finally dragged
him into a beautifully furnished room. Throwing herself on a lounge, she drew Jack to her.

7

Clasping her beautiful white, but ice-cold arms
around his neck, she whispered: "I love you
so much, angel-pie!"
"This is so very sudden, indeed, I just met
you Miss," stammered Jack—"you see, I
don't even know your name." "Name—you
are so funny, beloved mortal, what is this, a
name?"
"Yes, you're right, what's in a name? but
you see, I would like to know now how your
people call you."
"They call me Queen!" she answered
proudly.
"All right then Miss Queen, as I was
going— — — "
"Oh, precious, don't waste time talking,"
she interrupted him impatiently, "kiss me,
kiss me, my liberator, and tell me, that you
love me, as I love you, you spell-breaker!"
"Spell—
"Yes, don't you know that my father, who
wanted me to marry one of those ugly Tritons
down here, although he knew that I was crazy
about a navy-lieutenant,—I don't think of
him any more, now that I have you, my idol—
well, you see, at that time I refused to marry
that Triton and consequently my father—you
know him, he'll do a thing like that, when
he's mad, so he wove a spell over me, that I
should never feel love's joys and sorrows again
unless a mortal could stand the gaze of my eyes
for five minutes. I've tried in vain to find the
brave one;they all turned away blinded.You my
hero, my gallant Knight, looked into my eyes
longer than the required time. You have broken
the spell. I know what love is, I can love
again, love again!!!" she shouted, frantic with
joy, covering his mouth, his eyes, his whole
face with glowing kisses. Jack, who so far
had felt rather uneasy, did not object to this
kind of treatment—nor, why should he, would
you?—but, brought up to be polite, he returned her caresses with the same ardour— —
At last, when both really had to gasp for
breath, Jack jumped up and pulling out his
watch cried: "Oh, Great Scott, is it as late as
that; past eleven! ! I'm distressed, that I
overstayed the time. Eleven is your limit, I
suppose. But I had such a splendid time,
that I forgot all about the hour, I certainly
did enjoy the evening immensely. Good
night!"

"Where are you going, dear one. You
must stay here, of course, stay here with me,
your honey-girl, who loves you so! Be my
own!!"
"Oh, you are very kind and I appreciate it
all so much and I think so much of you and
I'll always be a brother to you, a friend in
need"—stammered Jack rather uncertain as
to the outcome of this adventure. He had
been receding slowly towards the door and
with a desperate leap tried to get out, but she
held him by his sleeve.
"Leave me," he cried, now getting really
mad, "this farce has been going on too long
any way."
"You are very polite indeed" she answered
in a somewhat changed voice, as Jack thought.
"The idea of your proposing to me—!"
"But, Mr.—"
"Aw, let me continue, I'm tired of this. I
don't love you at all. I love another girl at
home, a dear little girl with coal-black hair
and violet eyes!"
''This is too— —'
"Yes and above all I despise girls with fishtails! !!"
Yelling these words at the top of his voice
he made another attempt to gain the door
when he ran into—Eunice, his fair companion,
whom he now beheld standing before him
blazing with fury and who with tears in her
eyes and with a voice trembling with fury
cried: "Are you crazy, or what is the matter
with you? I thought you were a gentleman,
but I see you are a brute. So that the reward
for all my kindness? You were snoring in a
most outrageous way, so that everybody
laughed at you,so ',kindly enough pressed your
arm, only to hear you most rudely growl:
'Leave me! I don't love you! Don't propose to
me—The idea, as if / ever would consider
your love-making. But not enough with that;
you tell me, that you hate my red hair and
my green eyes—so far you always told me
they fascinated you—but the worst of all is
your daring to yell—so that everybody on
hoard can hear it, that you despise girls with—
oh it's incredible. Whom do you think you
have before you anyway?"
Bursting out into tears, she sank in her
chair sobbing violently. Jack had so far not
yet recovered his full consciousness. He had

stared at the beautiful creature, whom her
fury made all the more attractive, as if she
were a supernatural phantom. Her weeping
brought him back to earth; he simply could
not stand seeing a girl in tears, so timidly
laying his hand on her arm, he said with all
the gentleness and tenderness he was capable
of in a rueful tone: "But, dear Miss
Eunice— —"
But Eunice jumped up and ,with flashing
eyes, phosphorescent in the half-dark, she
cried: "How dare you touch my arm, how
dare you call me by my first name! Do not
dare to speak to me again!!"
And with a look expressing all the contempt
she, felt she turned around and left poor Jack
sitting dumbfounded in his chair. He sat
there silent and motionless for quite a while,
till finally shaking his head gravely, he said
H.
sophistically: ''Well I'll be— —!!"

THE NEWS-LETTER.

ST. JOHN'S, 0—HOPKINS, 0.
By the time this article appears the great
game with St. John's, in common with all
great games, will have become but a memory,
the echoes of the cheering that followed
Musser's wonderful one-hand back tackle will
be almost dead "in yon rich sky," the yells
that greeted Bridgman as he emerged, clad in
half a jersey and a lot of mud, after his twelveyard line plunge, will have likewise faded into
the rapidily receding past. And yet it is but
fittiiig that some attempt, at least, be made to
cause the memory of this game of games to
linger a while in the hearts of all true Hopkins
men,for it was the enthusiasm that the struggle evoked that proved that love for his
University is the great passion of the Hopkins
man, that he would brave rain, snow and
the various other kinds of weather, the
necessity of standing throughout an entire
game, the danger from Dr. Wood's boomerangs, and, above all, the expectation of almost
certain defeat, in order to come out and root
for his team.
It would be useless to speak here of the
meetings and yell practices that preceeded the
game, to tell bow "Purd'n's" voice sounded
like a fog-horn in the distance, with a spring
loose. Everybody remembers it all, and everybody remembers, too, the consequent magnificent showing the horde of the faithful made,
as, armed with its red, white and blue megaphones, it rooted for the pluckiest team the
University ever put out.
There is no need to speak here of the game
itself. The whole student-body was out there
and saw the confidence with which the St.
John's followers gave odds on the result, and
the surprise with which they viewed the gains
-made by the Hopkins back field. They were
surprised at the work of Abel, Bridgman,
Stollenwerck and Chesney, but they groaned
in very truth when their own much-vaunted
Captain Quimby, Bosley and Warfield failed
to pierce the adamant opposing line. Nor
were their end runs any more successful.
They played a great game, but the advantage
all the way was with the Black and Blue. The
odds were against Hopkins, but, backed by its
madly enthusiastic rooters and its brass band,
it put the glory of St. John's to the blush.
To be sure, the score does not give this

9

University a victory, but in reality the game
was more than a victory. It was a grand
triumph for Hopkins spirit.

HOPKINS, 7—UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND, 0.
Our eleven placed a fitting end to a season
that started anything but successfully by defeating the University of Maryland 7 to 0 in the
annual Thanksgiving game. An old saying
has it that "victory comes to him that waits,"
and that fits our case exactly. We have been
waiting the entire season for a victory and at
last our team has earned one. The credit of
this victory is due to the magnificent work of
the Black and Blue line. Every man showed
the "do or die" spirit and played with every
ounce of strength and spirit that he could
summon. Blank and Stockton were impregnable on the right wing and Morse and
Tilghman gave way but little before the continuous, hammering plunges of the Maroon
and Black backs. In fact our fellows held for
downs no less than five times.
The game was throughout a succession of
gruelling line plunges and punts. Open plays
were seldom used and when they were tried
they were unsuccessful. In offensive work
our fellows showed a decided reversal of form
from the St. John's game. Somehow or
other the plays would not work right. This
was probably due to the absence of Abel and
to the fact that Blake, the University captain,
covered Chesney closely during the entire
game and did not give him a chance to break
loose. Hopkins kicked to University of Maryland, who started immediately to march down
the field toward our goal. Our fellows held,
though, in about mid-field and started to do a

10

THE NEWS-LETTER.

little line plunging of their own, but the ball
was soon lost on a faulty forward pass. After
the pigskin had exchanged hands, Hopkins
advanced the ball as far as the 30 yard line,
where Stollenwerk tried for a field goal but
missed. After this the Marylanders steadily
gained ground and the half ended with the
ball in their possession on the 30 yard line.
Toward the end of the half Stollenwerk
sprained his shoulder and was replaced in the
second half by Chesney.
Our fellows started the second half strong.
Stewart received the kick-off and ran the ball
back ten yards before being tackled. Then a
double pass to McCabe netted ten more yards.
At this point our fellows were penallized for
an off-side play, and Chesney was forced to
punt. The ball was kicked perfectly and
sailed hard and low just over the quarterback's head and landed behind the University of Maryland's goal line. Wendell picked
up the ball and started to run with it but was
tackle behind the goal line by Morse, and the
score stood 2 to 0 in our favor. After this
came the hardest playing of the game.
University of Maryland sent its backs time
after time against our tackles, but our line
fought gamely and held their opponents for
downs three times within 20 yards of our
goal. It was only in the last five minutes of
play that the Black and Blue attack showed
its characteristic speed. Ridgely secured the
ball from a fumble on the Marylanders' 30
yard line. Two plunges failed and then our
team worked the neatest trick of the game.
The tackles were shifted over as if the play
was to be toward the center of the field, and
it was on this that the Maroon and Black
backs "bit," for Chesney fell back, made a
forward pass to Ridgely, who ran unmolested
to the two and a half yard line before being
tackled. Thcn after two downs, Stewart
plowed through left tackle for the touchdown. With two minutes more to play, the
University of Maryland team left the field in
disgust, with the referee, as they put it, but
in reality with themselves.
The game was the most successful of the
season from a pecuniary as well as an athletic
standpoint, for there were almost 3000 paid
admissions. Our rooters were also out in
force and cheered with a right good will.

The only disagreeable feature was the evident
ill-feeling of the University of Maryland
rooters toward Hopkins. The hissing of our
team as it came out on the field and the unnecessary rough tactics of the University of
Maryland team will hardly add to the feeling
of friendly rivalry that has heretofore existed
between the two universities.

JUNIORS, 6-FRESHMEN, 0.
Those who journeyed to Mt. Washington
on Friday, December 6, were well repaid for
any uncomfortableness which they may have
felt in the lower portions of their anatomy.
There was a fine crowd, quite as many as
attended the St. John's game, and there was
more than one fair face to spur on the warring
gladiators. Those same gladiators needed no
spurring, however! Rarely has there been
such intense rivalry between two classes.
In the first place the Freshmen had a larger
number of good individual players, than had
the Juniors. Then the Juniors lost Michael,
and this fact tended to' give the younger fellows more confidence. Realizing this, the
Juniors set to work with a determination that
was laudable, and in the end, won a victory
which was well deserved. Much credit is due
Captain Baily for the way in which he gathered his material together and developed a
well-drilled, plucky eleven.
The Freshmen were slower to organize, and
did not acquire team work to the degree that
the 1909 team did. Nevertheless, they put
up a plucky fight, and, in the first half, by
the use of two neat fortvard passes, put the
ball within ten yards of the posts, but could
not score. As a matter of fact, they played
better than was expected by them, but they
weakened visibly in the second half, when
they rarely made first down. Had it not
been for fumbling in the Junior line, the
Freshmen would not have loomed so dangerous as they did at times. As is usual in class
games, neither team could gain consistently
for any length of time.
The playing of Baily, the Junior captain, is
especially worthy of commendation. His
work was the bright part of.the game. Twice
he crossed the Freshman goal line, after most
brilliant runs, but one of the touchdowns was

The romantic glamour of the "days that

"Nothing bath grieved me yet but ancient woes,
Sea perils, or some long-ago farewell,
Or the last sunset cry of woundei Kings"
"Aware of other climes and lands
Of birth far-back, of lives in many stars."

In like strain Endymion (in the poem of
that name in the new volume)speaks to Selene
"I begin
To grieve for ancient wars and at the thought
Of women that have died long, long ago,
For sea-tossed heroes labouring towards the West."

Now-a-days when all the younger writers of
verse are exhibiting their command of intricate meters, there is something refreshing

14

THE NEWS-LETTER.

in the limited range of Mr. Phillips' poetic
gift. Save in the heroic complet—in which
form of verse he has been compared to no less
a poet than "glorious John"—he has little
power over rhyme. But in his blank-verse
the mantel of Tennyson seems to have fallen
upon him. There is no sign of imitiation but
of lineal descent from the master. In the
lines on Gladstone for instance, we note
"Thy voice had all the roaring of the wave,
And hoarse magnificence of rushing stones,
It had the murmur of Ionian bees—"

a line which at once recalls
"The moan of doves in innnemorial chins,
And murmuring of innumerable bees."

Of the poems in the new volume the "Quest
of Edith"—(for the body of Harold after
Sentac) is very dramatic and here again we
have the Tennysonian echo—this time from
"Harold." In the grim poem "Cities of
Hell" the poet presents the thought that
what we do in this world we must re-enact in
the next—
"Nothing done, or said, or thought,
Shall ever perish; none can ever die."

In the "Parting of Launcelot and Guinivere" we have a suggestion of what perhaps
took place sometime after Arthur left his
Queen and before she passed "to where beyoud these voices there is peace."
The volume closes with "lole," a tragedy
in one act. The old Biblical story of Jeptha's
Daughter is transferred to a classical setting
and around it Mr. Phillips has built up an
exquisitely artistic little play—full of genuine
pathos and real beauty.
There are many other poems which we cannot mention now. Altogether the volume is
distinctly pleasing. "Nero," Mr. Phillips'
last play, was a disappointment, and we are
therefore the more glad to see that he is as
capable as ever of sound workmanship, producing poetry of an high and lasting character.

THE DANCE.
The first of the Johns Hopkins Cotillon
Dances, was held on the night of December
the 7th, and proved to be a success. The
hall was tastefully decorated, the different
colors of the class banners showing up wonderfully well in the electric ligkt. The flag
of the Juniors, however, was somewhat conspicuous by its absence.

The dances began rather later than usual,
but by half-past nine o'clock, McCoy Hall
was well filled. A number of the Alumni
arrived during the evening and did their full
share towards making the dance a success.
The music, consisting of five pieces, was
excellent and the selections were very well
chosen. Supper was served about half-past
ten o'clock and enjoyed by everyone. After
supper there were eight dances, making a
total of sixteen. There were also a number
of "extras" and the dance was not over until
the clock struck twelve.
The only matter of regret is the failure to
appear on the part of many of the Patronesses.
As these dances are held under the auspices
of the fraternities, and are an attractive part
of the social life of the University, the presence of all of the Patronesses would be highly
appreciated.
The NEWS-LETTER takes this opportunity
to congratulate the Dance Committee on its
success and looks forward to other successful
cotillons under its direction.

BOOK NOTICE.
Wright's Short History of Greek Literature. By w
— ILMER CAVE WRIGHT, Ph.D.,
Associate Professor of Greek, Bryn Mawr
College. Cloth, 12mo, 543 pages. Price,
$1.50. American Book Company, New
York, Cincinnati and Chicago.
This volume affords a general survey of the
whole field of Greek literature, from Homer to
Julian. It is written rather from the literary
than the philological standpoint, and contains
such helpful features as numerous parallels
quoted from English literature, lists of standard
translations, and references to modern essays
dealing with the Greek masterpieces. At the
end of each chapter is a bibliography of the
more important literature of the topic treated.
It is a book which will appeal both to the general reader, and to the college student who
wishes to realize intelligently the significance

EDITORIAL.
2,2, 2t

F, at the commencement of the season, there was any doubt as to the
success of the Undergraduate Football Team, it has certainly been
It It
It
It
effectually dispelled. The splendid showing which our men made
1St
at the Saint John's game, the defeat of the University of Maryland,
the large crowds at Homewood on the 23rd and 28th, and the genF•
eral spirit and enthusiasm which have characterized these last few
weeks of the seas)n, are all certainly gratifying and convincing of
the pronounced success of the new regime. Never before have we
turned out a team so full of grit and hard-working spirit as the one
that lined up against Saint John's. Never before did enthusiasm
and "Hopkins spirit" reach so high a pitch as then. Never did the people of Baltimore
show such interest as to stand for two hours on a muddy field, in a driving rain, in order to
see Hopkins play football. A few may have done so before now—but when the number
exceeds a thousand, as in this case, it becomes remarkable.
The fact that the people were interested is owing to the real and hearty interest shown
and felt by the student-body. And the students were interested not only because it was a
Hopkins team, but an Undergraduate team, made up of their personal friends—not "individual stars from all over the country" (as someone has called our friends, the "medics ").
And because they were personal friends the students were with them heart and soul.
The Maryland game was less pleasing. Oil and water will not mix, and the ill feeling
displayed by the men from Lombard Street was in sharp contrast with the eager, yet friendly,
rivalry of our brass-buttoned friends from Annapolis. The students of the University of
Maryland don't lose much love over us, but what difference does that make, after all? We won
the game, and won it fairly and squarely.
Our narrow defeat by Western Maryland, our scoreless tie with Saint John's, and our
victory over the University of Maryland, all lead us to think and to hope that the Undergraduate team is something that will be with us always.

OME people say: "What will become of the Medical Students who
still love the game and desire exercise ?" It has been suggested
by a prominent member of the Faculty that the "medics," having
their own campus and their own leisure hours, should get together
and organize a team of their own • and practice at the Medical
School. They could then play the Undergrates at Homewood on
Wednesday afternoons. This would give them plenty of exercise,
and would improve the Undergraduate team without interferring
with its regular practices.

NE more word of comment on the football season. When the last
issue of the NEWS—LETTER appeared the enthusiasm over the Saint
John's game—to be played the next day—was at its height. The
short editorial on the poor rooting of the season was therefore
unnecessary. The showing made by the rooters at the last two
games was as good as that of our team—or nearly—and the hearty
support they received must be gratifying to each and every member
of our team.

Well, the first Hopkins Cotillon is over. It was a great success, of course. In fact
things are generally a success here. Everything went off in fine style last Saturday night and
reflected credit on the Board of Governors of the Cotillon Club. There will be another dance
next month—on the thirty-first of January, we believe. We hope that all who were at
McCoy Hall last Saturday will be back again then, and the unfortunate ones who were obliged
to be away will be able to come next time. We say "obliged" because surely no one would
be silly enough to stay away if he could help it.

With the football season past, and track yet to come, it does seem as if more interest
should be shown in the Glee Club. We do not speak of the Mandolin Club because it is getting
along excellently. But the Glee Club is not. With so good a leader as Mr. Ruth, there is no
excuse for so poor an attendance and such lack of enthusiasm and interest. Things have
been "whooping up" around here lately. Let's "whoop up" the Glee Club.

The grim approach of exams. next week prevented the publication of two issues of the

NEws-LETTER before Christmas. An issue should have appeared last Friday and one today
week, but even Editors are human and exams, have to be studied for! The NEWS—LETTER
wishes you all success in the exams., a very Merry Christmas and a fine time during the
holidays.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE EARLY ENGLISH NOVELISTS.

SmoLLETT.
In Smollett we find a man who showed life
as it was, probably better than did either
Richardson or Fielding. He, being the inferior
writer, did not improve his characters with
the jovial good fellowship of Fielding, nor
with the fanatical rigor of Richardson. And
thus, be it said to the shame of humanity, his
characters, being inferior in qualities, exceed
in truth, but only in one side of the truth.
Smollett was a more literal copyist of the side
of life•he chose, but he chose only one side.
To the good, the high, and the pure in life,
he was blind. His characters are, without
exception, repulsive creatures, almost incapable of a worthy emotion. In his preface he
gives his idea of the novel. For him it is a
convenient vehicle for satire; "the most entertaining and universally improving." His
characters appear to us as ruffians, yet Smollett regarded himself as a moralist, he considered himself a writer calculated to improve,
yet he repulses us.
Smollet always put his enemies in his books.
He was rancorous and implacable towards
them. In Roderick Random he draws us a
picture of his grandfather, his cousins, an
apothecary for whom he worked; all of whom
he detested and with good reason.
His first literary undertaking was a tragedy,
The Regicide, in which he had always an
overweening pride. He considered it,(a drama
in blank verse, upon the murder of James I.,)
a piece of great merit. But its results were
most unhappy to him. For ten years he clung
to it, polished it, changed it, and finally in
1749, after the appearance of Roderick Random, he published it. Needless to say, it was
a flat failure, "unappreciated," he said. He
had passed his medical examinations when he
first came to London. His money gave out
shortly afterwards and he obtained a berth as
surgeon's mate on the Cumberland. Here he
obtained his material for Roderick Random.
He soon left the navy and came back to London, where he practiced medicine with but
little success.
He had failed as a dramatist, as a doctor
and as a satirist, and he turned his attention

to the novel. Here he succeeded. The novel
was then popular, and in 1748 he catered to
the popular taste and produced Roderick
Random.
Roderick Random is not a character that
would appeal to our twentieth century minds.
Smollett, always an imitator of LeSage, here
follows out the "plan" of Gil Bias, a plan as
old as Petronius Arbiter. It is merely a
hurly-burly, rough and tumble story of life on
the road; but yet it contains a great deal of
Smollett's own life. The grandfather and
the cousins of Random are no other than
those of Smollett, with all their bad qualities
thrust into the foreground. The story of the
life at sea is taken from Smollett's own life.
He had been through all that he described
there. Yes, Roderick Random, poor derelict
of fate, is no other than Smollett himself. He
drags in his own unsuccessful Regicde under
the disguise of Mr. Melopoyn's drama. He
tells of his own experiences with the managers.
He attacks his former patron under the name
of Lord Strutwell, a man of large promises.
Here, too, he shows the influence of social
conditions upon him. Roderick Random is a
gentleman born; Strap is only a common
lackey: therefore Strap owes everything to
Random. He must be his devoted slave. In
France he finds Random forsaken and penniless. He comes to his aid, gives him his
money and his clothes; in fact, becomes his
valet. Of course, Random accepts. It is only
his due. And then, after taking Strap's money,
he may come home in a bad humor and vent
his spite upon the poor boy. Random finally
finishes by marrying Strap off to his wife's
maid, whom he knows to be a low woman.
But here Smollett rises to his highest as a
moralist,—the story of poor Miss Williams, a
true story, and one terrible in its very truth.
It is not fiction. When Smollett penned those
few pages, he was depicting one of the most
horrible phases of humanity. It is not only
Miss Williams' story, but it is the story of
many such another. There is no squeamishness or prudery here; it is a plain fact told in
a plain way. We all see the depravity of
human nature in its most appalling form. It
is a sickening presentation of a fearful truth.
In 1750, Peregrine Pickle was published.
Smollett introduces here people known to him

THE NEWS-LETTER.

and draws them so well that they are easily
recognized. Vet Peregrine Pickle is the best
thing he ever wrote. Of course the hero, like
all of Smollett's other heroes, is a hopeless
reprobate. Like Roderick Random, the novel
is made up of a string of adventures just
linked together, and, as a matter of fact, there
is no reason that it should ever come to an
end, except that, in the course of time, the
hero, being mortal, must die. But judging from
the modern Sherlock Holmes and Raffles, heroes
are perfectly able to come back to life and to
be run through countless volumes. Smollett,
as a humorist, strikes twelve in Peregrine
Pickle. Old Commodore Trunnion is one of
the most laughable characters I know, but he
is entirely different from any other of Smollett's characters. I always thought that he
got his idea for the commodore from Fielding's
Squire Western. However, in Peregrine Pickle
Smollett stamps himself as one of the foremost
humorists in the language. There is nothing
sharp and quick in his wit; it is of a very
broad order. If you can laugh at a comical
situation, and be impervious to the vulgarity
of it, you can enjoy Peregrine Pickle.
The weakest point in this novel is the longwinded account of the Lady of Quality. The
lady was the beautiful Lady Vane, whose
amours were described in her memoirs, which
Smollett practically reproduced. It is unnecessary, and it was put in chiefly for the benefit
of the scandal mongers.
His other novels are of much less importance
than these two. Ferdenand Count Fathom,
The Adventures of an Atom, Sir Launeelot
Graves, and Humphrey Clinker, complete the
list. Of these, the first and the last are
worthy of mention.
Ferdenand Count Fathom, is the adventures
of a young man, absolutely devoid of conscience, gratitude and courage, and incapable
of a genuine emotion. This admirable character betrays his master who had raised him,
lays traps for young girls, and does a variety of
other things on the same order. A more
sickening character has never been drawn in
the whole of English literature. Finally,
the hero reforms and marries a girl whom he
had ruined before. Virtue came out supreme.
But to say the least, it is not a moral or edifying tale.

5

Humphrey Clinker, is the last book Smollett
ever wrote, and in some respects the best of
them all. Thackery said it was the most
laughable book ever written. Certainly it is
the kindest Sm011ett ever wrote. In it he
forgives everybody, even his own relations.
What could be more laughable than old
Tabitha Brambles' persistent attempts at love.
The book is a veritable history. Smollett
wrote of his own country, Scotland. All in
all, HumPhrey Clinker is the most "good
natured" novel of Smollett's.
Smollett wrote of the low classes, and in
this respect he was the forerunner of Dickens.
But in turn, LeSage was the forerunner of
Smollett. It is only, however, in the class of
characters, that there is any resemblance to
Dickens. Smollett wrote of the low classes
because he knew them. His favorite trick
was to take for a hero a gentleman born, and
then run him, surrounded by the lowest
society in England, through numberless chapters.
The point in Smollett's novels most easily
assailed is the moral side. He claimed to be
a moralist, but is he? The story of poor Miss
Williams is undoubtedly written with the
moral object in view. It is held up in all its
horror. Vice is vice, and its consequences
are all put down. But with the exception of
this, I do not think that there is anything in
Smollett calculated to have a good moral
effect. Of course we can consider Fathom as
a sort of terrible example, but how many of
the readers do? Is there anything calculated
to have a moral effect in Peregrine Pickle? We
fairly split our sides over some parts of it, but
it doesn't make us any better. Smollett, I
think, uses the cloak of a moralist as a means
to introduce the low and the obscene. He has
neither the rigor of Richardson nor the open
bluffness of Fielding. He wants to be like
Fielding, but he hasn't the courage to he so
openly. No; Smollett is not moral. He is a
great humorist, but he is not a moralist.
With Smollett passed away the old rough
and tumble novel of humor, of life on the
road. It was for the best. They had diverted
the stream of literature towards the realms of
fiction. Their successors were mightier than
they were, but still we do not want to discard
them completely. At the present day they

THE NEWS-LETTER.

6

are but little read, and perhaps that is for the
best. There are two ways to be a moralist.
One is to drag the reader down through the
filth and mire of human depravity till, disgusted and nauseated, one turns in sheer desperation away. This is the course of the early
novelists. The other is to so inspire the
reader, with the beauty of the true and the
high things in life that the love for them
completely crowds out the low and the vulgar.
Here, one turns to the higher things, not
through disgust and hatred for the low, but
for the love of the better.
Let us appreciate Fielding, Richardson and
Smollett as best we can. They compose a
field of literature comparatively unread. I do
not seek to defend them, but I maintain that
they, with all their coarseness and obscenity,
are far better than our modern fiction. Perhaps it is better to let them stay unread. They
would not be appreciated by twentieth
century minds. Some would throw them
aside, half read, disgusted and sick of them.
Others would keep on in delight. To them it
would be a fresh supply of 'gay reading." A
few, a very few, would appreciate them. It
is to these few, then, that falls the duty to
keep alive and fresh the memory of RichardW.
son, Fielding and Smollett.
[THE END.]

under my head and the other one—yes, that's
right; I hate to get the draught on my back
—oh, it's fine to be wrapped up so nicely.
Now I'll try to slumber a little while—I'm
sure I'll dream about you, Mr. Hall!"
"In that case, I needn't wish you pleasant
dreams, Miss Grosset."
"Well, of all the conceit!! Why are men so
conceited! Girls never are!"
"Never!"
"Now this irony again, this sardonic sneer!
It makes me nervous!"
"Sleep is good for overstrained nerves!"
"Thank you, I'll take the hint; I'll go to
sleep immediately. I won't say another word

to you, tonight, and I certainly shall not
dream about you!"
"Pleasant dreams then," came the dry
answer.
"You're a hopeless case, absolutely—"
This was the last he could hear of this
violent outburst of utter disgust, for the last
words were spoken from under the rug, which
she had drawn up over her face, to protect it
against the cool evening breeze.
For a few moments he stood there motionless, looking down on this huge pile of
cushions and rugs on the steamer-chair,
crowned by an aureola of beautiful auburn
hair beneath a white tam o'sbanter, and shaking his head he slowly walked away.
The big liner ploughed its way majestically
thru the exceptionally smooth waters of the
Atlantic Ocean. The quietude of the desert
reigned on board. All the passengers were
comfortably wrapped up in their steamerchairs, either enjoying a short after-dinner
nap, or dreaming with eyes wide open.
From the stern the soft, plaintive tunes of a
violin were heard, played by one of the crew
perchance in honor of his distant sweetheart.
Jack Hall was leaning over the railing, gazing down upon the silvery pathway caused by
the moon on the gentle undulating waves.
He could not help thinking of those dangerous green siren eyes, now closed in sleep
under the protecting rug. They had not
failed to bewitch him the first time he had
looked into then when at the first dinner on
board he had found her sitting next to him.
Since that moment he had been completely
under their spell and had become Eunice
Grosset's most faithful and perhaps most
successful suitor, cutting out all of his many
rivals.
He enjoyed the privilege of having his
steamer-chair next to hers, he was allowed to
wrap her up and arrange her numerous
pillows and to carry out her many small
orders. Sure, she was so sweet and fascinating and he felt as if they were friends of old
and he knew she felt the same way.
Jack Hall had not stirred for the last thirty
minutes, gazing upon the play of the moon
rays on the water it seemed to him as if some
mermaids were dancing there, and strange to
say, one of them was fixing her green phos-

THE NEWS-LETTER.

phorescent eyes upon him—why, she looked
like Eunice, he thought. "You're moonstruck, old chap," he murmured, •'I'll have
to tell Eunice about my vision." He found
Eunice sound asleep and so—faute de mieux
—followed her example and was soon slumbering away to the isle of dreams.
All of a sudden, the liner stopped abruptly,
throwing everyone on the floor. Shrieking,
running,—yelling. "Something wrong with
the propellers," howled the Chief Engineer
after a 'few moments of anxious expectation.
Two men were ordered to investigate. After
a short while they reappeared above the railing
—a broad grill on their faces. They reported
that the propellers were entangled in a mass
of sea-weed and that there were some mermaids down there, one of whom demanded
the youngest man on board to come down
to her immediately, or else the whole ship
would be wrecked.
Jack was looking around in order to find to
find tile poor chap who would have to sacrifice himself for the benefit of his fellowpassengers, when the Captain tipped him on
his shoulder. "Mr. Hall," he said, "the
Chief Steward after looking over the passenger
list, informs me, that you are the youngest
man, and so, I'm afraid, you're the man
wanted down there."
"What I, am I the youngest?" yelled Jack.
'Yes, I'm sorry.'
"So am I. I'm not going down there."
"Well we'll see about that" said the Captain cruelly, and before Jack knew what happened he felt himself lifted up by brutal hands
and thrown overboard. It seemed to him as
if he were flying thru the air for more than
an hour, before he finally safely landed in an
immense shell at the side of the beautiful mermaid who had stared at him, while he was
watching her dancing.
"Take this stone, sweet mortal, it will protect you from the waters," she said to our
speechless Jack, *handing him a- big emerald.
She then blew a silver-whistle and instantly
the shell began to sink slowly until it finally
landed before a large grot. The mermaid
took Jack by the hand and led him thru the
labyrinth of passage until she finally dragged
him into a beautifully furnished room. Throwing herself on a lounge, she drew Jack to her.

7

Clasping her beautiful white, but ice-cold arms
around his neck, she whispered: "I love you
so much, angel-pie!"
"This is so very sudden, indeed, I just met
you Miss," stammered Jack—"you see, I
don't even know your name." "Name—you
are so funny, beloved mortal, what is this, a
name?"
"Yes, you're right, what's in a name? but
you see, I would like to know now how your
people call you."
"They call me Queen!" she answered
proudly.
"All right then Miss Queen, as I was
going— — — "
"Oh, precious, don't waste time talking,"
she interrupted him impatiently, "kiss me,
kiss me, my liberator, and tell me, that you
love me, as I love you, you spell-breaker!"
"Spell—
"Yes, don't you know that my father, who
wanted me to marry one of those ugly Tritons
down here, although he knew that I was crazy
about a navy-lieutenant,—I don't think of
him any more, now that I have you, my idol—
well, you see, at that time I refused to marry
that Triton and consequently my father—you
know him, he'll do a thing like that, when
he's mad, so he wove a spell over me, that I
should never feel love's joys and sorrows again
unless a mortal could stand the gaze of my eyes
for five minutes. I've tried in vain to find the
brave one;they all turned away blinded.You my
hero, my gallant Knight, looked into my eyes
longer than the required time. You have broken
the spell. I know what love is, I can love
again, love again!!!" she shouted, frantic with
joy, covering his mouth, his eyes, his whole
face with glowing kisses. Jack, who so far
had felt rather uneasy, did not object to this
kind of treatment—nor, why should he, would
you?—but, brought up to be polite, he returned her caresses with the same ardour— —
At last, when both really had to gasp for
breath, Jack jumped up and pulling out his
watch cried: "Oh, Great Scott, is it as late as
that; past eleven! ! I'm distressed, that I
overstayed the time. Eleven is your limit, I
suppose. But I had such a splendid time,
that I forgot all about the hour, I certainly
did enjoy the evening immensely. Good
night!"

"Where are you going, dear one. You
must stay here, of course, stay here with me,
your honey-girl, who loves you so! Be my
own!!"
"Oh, you are very kind and I appreciate it
all so much and I think so much of you and
I'll always be a brother to you, a friend in
need"—stammered Jack rather uncertain as
to the outcome of this adventure. He had
been receding slowly towards the door and
with a desperate leap tried to get out, but she
held him by his sleeve.
"Leave me," he cried, now getting really
mad, "this farce has been going on too long
any way."
"You are very polite indeed" she answered
in a somewhat changed voice, as Jack thought.
"The idea of your proposing to me—!"
"But, Mr.—"
"Aw, let me continue, I'm tired of this. I
don't love you at all. I love another girl at
home, a dear little girl with coal-black hair
and violet eyes!"
''This is too— —'
"Yes and above all I despise girls with fishtails! !!"
Yelling these words at the top of his voice
he made another attempt to gain the door
when he ran into—Eunice, his fair companion,
whom he now beheld standing before him
blazing with fury and who with tears in her
eyes and with a voice trembling with fury
cried: "Are you crazy, or what is the matter
with you? I thought you were a gentleman,
but I see you are a brute. So that the reward
for all my kindness? You were snoring in a
most outrageous way, so that everybody
laughed at you,so ',kindly enough pressed your
arm, only to hear you most rudely growl:
'Leave me! I don't love you! Don't propose to
me—The idea, as if / ever would consider
your love-making. But not enough with that;
you tell me, that you hate my red hair and
my green eyes—so far you always told me
they fascinated you—but the worst of all is
your daring to yell—so that everybody on
hoard can hear it, that you despise girls with—
oh it's incredible. Whom do you think you
have before you anyway?"
Bursting out into tears, she sank in her
chair sobbing violently. Jack had so far not
yet recovered his full consciousness. He had

stared at the beautiful creature, whom her
fury made all the more attractive, as if she
were a supernatural phantom. Her weeping
brought him back to earth; he simply could
not stand seeing a girl in tears, so timidly
laying his hand on her arm, he said with all
the gentleness and tenderness he was capable
of in a rueful tone: "But, dear Miss
Eunice— —"
But Eunice jumped up and ,with flashing
eyes, phosphorescent in the half-dark, she
cried: "How dare you touch my arm, how
dare you call me by my first name! Do not
dare to speak to me again!!"
And with a look expressing all the contempt
she, felt she turned around and left poor Jack
sitting dumbfounded in his chair. He sat
there silent and motionless for quite a while,
till finally shaking his head gravely, he said
H.
sophistically: ''Well I'll be— —!!"

THE NEWS-LETTER.

ST. JOHN'S, 0—HOPKINS, 0.
By the time this article appears the great
game with St. John's, in common with all
great games, will have become but a memory,
the echoes of the cheering that followed
Musser's wonderful one-hand back tackle will
be almost dead "in yon rich sky," the yells
that greeted Bridgman as he emerged, clad in
half a jersey and a lot of mud, after his twelveyard line plunge, will have likewise faded into
the rapidily receding past. And yet it is but
fittiiig that some attempt, at least, be made to
cause the memory of this game of games to
linger a while in the hearts of all true Hopkins
men,for it was the enthusiasm that the struggle evoked that proved that love for his
University is the great passion of the Hopkins
man, that he would brave rain, snow and
the various other kinds of weather, the
necessity of standing throughout an entire
game, the danger from Dr. Wood's boomerangs, and, above all, the expectation of almost
certain defeat, in order to come out and root
for his team.
It would be useless to speak here of the
meetings and yell practices that preceeded the
game, to tell bow "Purd'n's" voice sounded
like a fog-horn in the distance, with a spring
loose. Everybody remembers it all, and everybody remembers, too, the consequent magnificent showing the horde of the faithful made,
as, armed with its red, white and blue megaphones, it rooted for the pluckiest team the
University ever put out.
There is no need to speak here of the game
itself. The whole student-body was out there
and saw the confidence with which the St.
John's followers gave odds on the result, and
the surprise with which they viewed the gains
-made by the Hopkins back field. They were
surprised at the work of Abel, Bridgman,
Stollenwerck and Chesney, but they groaned
in very truth when their own much-vaunted
Captain Quimby, Bosley and Warfield failed
to pierce the adamant opposing line. Nor
were their end runs any more successful.
They played a great game, but the advantage
all the way was with the Black and Blue. The
odds were against Hopkins, but, backed by its
madly enthusiastic rooters and its brass band,
it put the glory of St. John's to the blush.
To be sure, the score does not give this

9

University a victory, but in reality the game
was more than a victory. It was a grand
triumph for Hopkins spirit.

HOPKINS, 7—UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND, 0.
Our eleven placed a fitting end to a season
that started anything but successfully by defeating the University of Maryland 7 to 0 in the
annual Thanksgiving game. An old saying
has it that "victory comes to him that waits,"
and that fits our case exactly. We have been
waiting the entire season for a victory and at
last our team has earned one. The credit of
this victory is due to the magnificent work of
the Black and Blue line. Every man showed
the "do or die" spirit and played with every
ounce of strength and spirit that he could
summon. Blank and Stockton were impregnable on the right wing and Morse and
Tilghman gave way but little before the continuous, hammering plunges of the Maroon
and Black backs. In fact our fellows held for
downs no less than five times.
The game was throughout a succession of
gruelling line plunges and punts. Open plays
were seldom used and when they were tried
they were unsuccessful. In offensive work
our fellows showed a decided reversal of form
from the St. John's game. Somehow or
other the plays would not work right. This
was probably due to the absence of Abel and
to the fact that Blake, the University captain,
covered Chesney closely during the entire
game and did not give him a chance to break
loose. Hopkins kicked to University of Maryland, who started immediately to march down
the field toward our goal. Our fellows held,
though, in about mid-field and started to do a

10

THE NEWS-LETTER.

little line plunging of their own, but the ball
was soon lost on a faulty forward pass. After
the pigskin had exchanged hands, Hopkins
advanced the ball as far as the 30 yard line,
where Stollenwerk tried for a field goal but
missed. After this the Marylanders steadily
gained ground and the half ended with the
ball in their possession on the 30 yard line.
Toward the end of the half Stollenwerk
sprained his shoulder and was replaced in the
second half by Chesney.
Our fellows started the second half strong.
Stewart received the kick-off and ran the ball
back ten yards before being tackled. Then a
double pass to McCabe netted ten more yards.
At this point our fellows were penallized for
an off-side play, and Chesney was forced to
punt. The ball was kicked perfectly and
sailed hard and low just over the quarterback's head and landed behind the University of Maryland's goal line. Wendell picked
up the ball and started to run with it but was
tackle behind the goal line by Morse, and the
score stood 2 to 0 in our favor. After this
came the hardest playing of the game.
University of Maryland sent its backs time
after time against our tackles, but our line
fought gamely and held their opponents for
downs three times within 20 yards of our
goal. It was only in the last five minutes of
play that the Black and Blue attack showed
its characteristic speed. Ridgely secured the
ball from a fumble on the Marylanders' 30
yard line. Two plunges failed and then our
team worked the neatest trick of the game.
The tackles were shifted over as if the play
was to be toward the center of the field, and
it was on this that the Maroon and Black
backs "bit," for Chesney fell back, made a
forward pass to Ridgely, who ran unmolested
to the two and a half yard line before being
tackled. Thcn after two downs, Stewart
plowed through left tackle for the touchdown. With two minutes more to play, the
University of Maryland team left the field in
disgust, with the referee, as they put it, but
in reality with themselves.
The game was the most successful of the
season from a pecuniary as well as an athletic
standpoint, for there were almost 3000 paid
admissions. Our rooters were also out in
force and cheered with a right good will.

The only disagreeable feature was the evident
ill-feeling of the University of Maryland
rooters toward Hopkins. The hissing of our
team as it came out on the field and the unnecessary rough tactics of the University of
Maryland team will hardly add to the feeling
of friendly rivalry that has heretofore existed
between the two universities.

JUNIORS, 6-FRESHMEN, 0.
Those who journeyed to Mt. Washington
on Friday, December 6, were well repaid for
any uncomfortableness which they may have
felt in the lower portions of their anatomy.
There was a fine crowd, quite as many as
attended the St. John's game, and there was
more than one fair face to spur on the warring
gladiators. Those same gladiators needed no
spurring, however! Rarely has there been
such intense rivalry between two classes.
In the first place the Freshmen had a larger
number of good individual players, than had
the Juniors. Then the Juniors lost Michael,
and this fact tended to' give the younger fellows more confidence. Realizing this, the
Juniors set to work with a determination that
was laudable, and in the end, won a victory
which was well deserved. Much credit is due
Captain Baily for the way in which he gathered his material together and developed a
well-drilled, plucky eleven.
The Freshmen were slower to organize, and
did not acquire team work to the degree that
the 1909 team did. Nevertheless, they put
up a plucky fight, and, in the first half, by
the use of two neat fortvard passes, put the
ball within ten yards of the posts, but could
not score. As a matter of fact, they played
better than was expected by them, but they
weakened visibly in the second half, when
they rarely made first down. Had it not
been for fumbling in the Junior line, the
Freshmen would not have loomed so dangerous as they did at times. As is usual in class
games, neither team could gain consistently
for any length of time.
The playing of Baily, the Junior captain, is
especially worthy of commendation. His
work was the bright part of.the game. Twice
he crossed the Freshman goal line, after most
brilliant runs, but one of the touchdowns was

THE NEW BOOK SHELF.
The "New Poems" of Stephen Phillips
which appeared some weeks since in England,
have now been published in this country.
It is a pity that the work of so high and
trite a poet should almost always be concerned
with the sadness and gloom of life. His
poems seems an echo of the words in
Atalanta."

"For if you don't I really might
Snatch just one kiss here in the light—
But there 'tis dark; the fire burns low,
And we need fear nor friend nor foe—
"His life is a watch or a vision
We'll not be found, tis hidden quite—
Between a sleep and a sleep,"
My Christmas Girl!" or even of the more awful words of Webster
TRioLET.

"Their life a general mist of error
Their death a hideous storm of terror."

She stood 'neath the holly
And not mistletoe.
Little Miss Dolly,
She stood 'neath the holly,
But 1 felt so jolly

* * * * * *

The romantic glamour of the "days that
are no more" has had a strong influence over
much of Mr. Phillips's work. In his earliest
play Francesca says—

She stood 'neath the holly
And not mistletoe!

and by the side of Marpessa, Idas is

IV.—A RONDEI,.
On Christmas night when all our games are
done
The children kissed and put to bed each one

"Nothing bath grieved me yet but ancient woes,
Sea perils, or some long-ago farewell,
Or the last sunset cry of woundei Kings"
"Aware of other climes and lands
Of birth far-back, of lives in many stars."

In like strain Endymion (in the poem of
that name in the new volume)speaks to Selene
"I begin
To grieve for ancient wars and at the thought
Of women that have died long, long ago,
For sea-tossed heroes labouring towards the West."

Now-a-days when all the younger writers of
verse are exhibiting their command of intricate meters, there is something refreshing

14

THE NEWS-LETTER.

in the limited range of Mr. Phillips' poetic
gift. Save in the heroic complet—in which
form of verse he has been compared to no less
a poet than "glorious John"—he has little
power over rhyme. But in his blank-verse
the mantel of Tennyson seems to have fallen
upon him. There is no sign of imitiation but
of lineal descent from the master. In the
lines on Gladstone for instance, we note
"Thy voice had all the roaring of the wave,
And hoarse magnificence of rushing stones,
It had the murmur of Ionian bees—"

a line which at once recalls
"The moan of doves in innnemorial chins,
And murmuring of innumerable bees."

Of the poems in the new volume the "Quest
of Edith"—(for the body of Harold after
Sentac) is very dramatic and here again we
have the Tennysonian echo—this time from
"Harold." In the grim poem "Cities of
Hell" the poet presents the thought that
what we do in this world we must re-enact in
the next—
"Nothing done, or said, or thought,
Shall ever perish; none can ever die."

In the "Parting of Launcelot and Guinivere" we have a suggestion of what perhaps
took place sometime after Arthur left his
Queen and before she passed "to where beyoud these voices there is peace."
The volume closes with "lole," a tragedy
in one act. The old Biblical story of Jeptha's
Daughter is transferred to a classical setting
and around it Mr. Phillips has built up an
exquisitely artistic little play—full of genuine
pathos and real beauty.
There are many other poems which we cannot mention now. Altogether the volume is
distinctly pleasing. "Nero," Mr. Phillips'
last play, was a disappointment, and we are
therefore the more glad to see that he is as
capable as ever of sound workmanship, producing poetry of an high and lasting character.

THE DANCE.
The first of the Johns Hopkins Cotillon
Dances, was held on the night of December
the 7th, and proved to be a success. The
hall was tastefully decorated, the different
colors of the class banners showing up wonderfully well in the electric ligkt. The flag
of the Juniors, however, was somewhat conspicuous by its absence.

The dances began rather later than usual,
but by half-past nine o'clock, McCoy Hall
was well filled. A number of the Alumni
arrived during the evening and did their full
share towards making the dance a success.
The music, consisting of five pieces, was
excellent and the selections were very well
chosen. Supper was served about half-past
ten o'clock and enjoyed by everyone. After
supper there were eight dances, making a
total of sixteen. There were also a number
of "extras" and the dance was not over until
the clock struck twelve.
The only matter of regret is the failure to
appear on the part of many of the Patronesses.
As these dances are held under the auspices
of the fraternities, and are an attractive part
of the social life of the University, the presence of all of the Patronesses would be highly
appreciated.
The NEWS-LETTER takes this opportunity
to congratulate the Dance Committee on its
success and looks forward to other successful
cotillons under its direction.

WITH NO APOLOGIES TO CHAUCER
A Freshman there was, war and wys also
That unto Hopkins hadde just y-go,
In all this world ne was there noon him lyk
To mightie Junior scornfully to spyk;
His hosen weren of fyn scarlet reed
And brown derbie kepte he upon his heed;
Of tyes and robes hadde he many oon
So great a dandy swell was nowher noon.
But now the Junior dorste make avaunt
He wiste a man that wolde be repentaunt:
This Junior was a verray parfit hazier
A lovyer, and a lusty Bacheler.—
Though not of Artes hadde IL! his degree;
At many a noble rushe hadde he be.
Of Budweise many a glass had he y-drawe
And, certainly, he was a good felowe.
And so bifel, by aventure or charge,
This freshman roped was into the Hopkins
cage.
!!!
! !!
!! !
Anon, to drawen the curtain from the scene,
The Freshmaii cometh forth not quite so clene
But just as one encombred in the myre
With tamed expressioun and closed eye.
In all the classes four noon is that can
—As does this freshie, this obsequious man
Since his descent into the Hopkins cage—
So much of reverence and fair langage.
And, now then Freshmen: tak this as a signe
Of the mighte and sway of NINETEENNINE.

BOOK NOTICE.
Wright's Short History of Greek Literature. By w
— ILMER CAVE WRIGHT, Ph.D.,
Associate Professor of Greek, Bryn Mawr
College. Cloth, 12mo, 543 pages. Price,
$1.50. American Book Company, New
York, Cincinnati and Chicago.
This volume affords a general survey of the
whole field of Greek literature, from Homer to
Julian. It is written rather from the literary
than the philological standpoint, and contains
such helpful features as numerous parallels
quoted from English literature, lists of standard
translations, and references to modern essays
dealing with the Greek masterpieces. At the
end of each chapter is a bibliography of the
more important literature of the topic treated.
It is a book which will appeal both to the general reader, and to the college student who
wishes to realize intelligently the significance
and relations to the whole of the classic masterpieces he is reading.
